{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3129327,"name":"Ashli Sincere","username":"AshliSincere","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ashlisincere/{size}/156361_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-18T23:11:01.894Z","cooked":"

Hi! A robot design that we’ve been thinking about would require a supination/pronating motion on our intake, and I was wondering if there are any examples of this being done before to draw inspiration from?

Types Of Wrist Motion

Heres some drawings for context

Side On View (The idea is that the intake will be able to pass through the robot so you can intake on one side of the bot and score on the other side without rotating your robot)

fulldrawing756×568 40.6 KB

Closer Intake Drawing

intake756×568 33.8 KB

Any help is much appreciated :​D

I don’t know of any specific examples in FRC, but you might take inspiration from the traditional 6DoF arm, which usually includes a pro/supination joint as the last before the end effector.

May have to go back a few years… it has been a while since there was a reason to flip a game piece like this, so my last two frc examples are related, not exact.

2015 - 118 had a can grabber/flipper at the beginning of the season (in reveal vid)

2016 - 330 could aim the end of their arm

2019 - 2767 elevator carriage “Biscuit” to swap sides the game piece was scored on - I designed this so I could give a little detail on it

Probably a host of FTC examples out there.

I’ll update this if I can think of any more

To put it on a telescoping tube:
In short I would focus on having two bushings spaced out a fair distance on the inner part of the climber arm and a ~1" Aluminum tube going through those, lubricated. This should at least resist the moment loads while providing an axial degree of freedom. you will need to find a way to retain it, perhaps a 1" shaft collar. If you are using pneumatics and only care about flipping 180 that would be my suggestion, have a cylinder or two move a lever arm to spin the thing, probably lighter than a motor and sprocket out on the end. You can control how fast it spins with the in-line flow limiters.

There might be some clues in here: ServoBlock™ (Standard Size, 25 Tooth Spline, Hub-Shaft) - goBILDA . These parts are often used in FTC, but they’re heavy duty and capable of higher loads.
